etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Mordecai Cooke (1825–1914), naturalist and mycologist. From meso- + spore

definitions: The middle layer of the wall of any of several types of three-layered spores (e.g. the megaspore of a clubmoss or the zygospore of a zygnemaceous alga).
A one-celled teleutospore occurring in species of rust fungus which normally produce two-celled teleutospores.
